Module Contents

type_forge.utils.string_format.camel_to_snake(name)[source]

Convert a camelCase or PascalCase string to snake_case.

Transforms identifiers from camelCase or PascalCase convention to snake_case for consistent naming across the system.

Parameters:

name (str) – The camelCase or PascalCase string to convert

Returns:

The equivalent snake_case string

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> camel_to_snake("camelCase")
'camel_case'
>>> camel_to_snake("PascalCase")
'pascal_case'
>>> camel_to_snake("HTTPResponse")
'http_response'
>>> camel_to_snake("")
''

Note

Handles special cases with consecutive uppercase letters correctly.

type_forge.utils.string_format.format_message(subject, value)[source]

Format a message by combining a string subject with an integer value.

Creates a precisely formatted string combining the subject and value in a grammatically coherent structure.

Parameters:

  • subject (str) – The subject of the message. Must be a valid string.

  • value (int) – The numerical value associated with the subject. Must be an integer.

Returns:

A formatted message combining the subject and value.

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> format_message("Temperature", 72)
'Temperature has a value of 72.'

Note

This function performs no validation on the inputs beyond typing.

type_forge.utils.string_format.format_type_name(typ)[source]

Format a type into a clean, readable string representation.

Converts Python type objects into standardized string representations for consistent display and logging. Handles generics, unions, and nested types.

Parameters:

typ (Type[object]) – The type to format into a string

Returns:

A standardized string representation of the type

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> format_type_name(int)
'int'
>>> format_type_name(List[int])
'List[int]'
>>> format_type_name(Dict[str, Optional[int]])
'Dict[str, Optional[int]]'

Note

This function handles generic types, union types, and nested types.

type_forge.utils.string_format.pluralize(word)[source]

Convert a singular word to its plural form using simple English rules.

Applies common English pluralization rules to transform singular nouns to their plural forms.

Parameters:

word (str) – The singular word to pluralize

Returns:

The pluralized form of the word

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> pluralize("cat")
'cats'
>>> pluralize("class")
'classes'
>>> pluralize("study")
'studies'
>>> pluralize("box")
'boxes'
>>> pluralize("child")  # Special cases are not handled
'childs'

Note

Handles common English pluralization rules but not irregular nouns.

type_forge.utils.string_format.snake_to_camel(name)[source]

Convert a snake_case string to camelCase.

Transforms identifiers from snake_case convention to camelCase for consistent naming across the system.

Parameters:

name (str) – The snake_case string to convert

Returns:

The equivalent camelCase string

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> snake_to_camel("snake_case")
'snakeCase'
>>> snake_to_camel("http_response")
'httpResponse'
>>> snake_to_camel("__private_var")
'__privateVar'
>>> snake_to_camel("")
''

Note

Preserves leading underscores for private/protected identifiers.

type_forge.utils.string_format.standardize_typename(name)[source]

Standardize a type name for consistent representation.

Converts various representations of type names to a standardized format, handling common variations and aliases.

Parameters:

name (str) – The type name to standardize

Returns:

The standardized type name

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> standardize_typename("int")
'int'
>>> standardize_typename("integer")
'int'
>>> standardize_typename("str")
'str'
>>> standardize_typename("string")
'str'
>>> standardize_typename("bool")
'bool'
>>> standardize_typename("boolean")
'bool'

Note

Normalizes common type name variations to their Python equivalents.
